titleStmt.title: John W. Elliot to James F. Robinson
CWG8667

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, James F. Robinson: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons, Remissions, and Respites, 1862-1863

body.p: To his Excellency Jas Robinson Governor &c

The affiant John W. Elliott says that at the February Term 1863 of the Bracken Circuit Court, he was presented by the grand Jury of Bracken Circuit Court, for selling Liquor to slaves and that as soon as he heard of it -- he went to the court. and entered his appearance and confessed Judgement and was find by the Court $5000

He says the circumstances are as follows There was an oyster party at his house -- and the Negro Mentioned in the Indictment was there waiting on the young men present -- and that during the evening -- he gave the slave a glass of Wine -- Not intending to violate any Law. That he did it unthoughtedly -- and Not intending to do any wrong. He ask your Excellency to remit so much of the fine -- as is due the Commonwealth

Sworn to by Jno W Elliott
Feby 26th 1863
Jno H Bonde
Examiner
